28030161.review:
Secrets of Grindea so far is a great game. Plenty of challenges both in  Story and Arcade Mode. Skills and character movement are responsive, and there are subtle cancellations that make the combat somewhat customizable. The skill choices aren't limited in any way other than being less effective if you use certain weapons. The skills require a "charge" and unlock more powerful versions once you've leveled up the skills enough.

Story-wise it has some solid moments. A cinematic-driven story with a lot of humor/comic relief. There are some potential plot twists starting to evolve and that may give the story a bit of a turn and spice things up a bit. Overall while i'm not a fan of story/cinema in games, it was enjoyable and not too dramatic or overdone like what a lot of titles do.

Creativity-wise, there is a recipe-driven crafting system. You essentially grind some items and are able to put the items together and figure out what the "unknown item" is. The character's house is being implemented and there is potential that players will be able to add particular items to that house, and perhaps in a certain order. Other than that players also have some room on choosing their combat style. A player may be a meteor summoning "shieldmaiden" that uses a magical spear instead of the typical sword/staff.

Other than that there's still a lot of the game being developed. This review was for a particular steam badge. ;) I'd have written a review upon official release instead of during early access, and likely will udpate this review once SoG is complete.

Extremely fun (albeit slowly developed) co-op action RPG. The graphics are quality 2D with fantastic animation. The combat is centered around skillful timing and utilizing a fairly large number of skills (each of which has different uses/mechanics).

Short of that, if quality remains consistent, it should be very well worth picking up once fully released.

27956960.review:
This game is very promising. It may be early access but don't let that deter you as it has tons of content to keep you interested. If you're a fan of games like Final Fantasy, the Legend of Zelda, Fantasy Life or other similar RPG games you'll find joy here. The 4th Wall is something it likes to smash down quite often as you'll come across many Easter Eggs and reference, one being the Triforce laying on the ground or a character mentioning "/" commands. Secrets of Grindea knows it's a video game and uses that to it's pleasure since it allows it to make tons of jokes. Heck you start out from a town called "Startington". 

The characters are also quite pleasing to meet. Your father has a backstory and a driving motive that I find interesting to explore, as you plung further into the game his past is opened up to a point where you realize you aren't the only character of importance running around Grindea. The games controls seemed odd to me at first but I later came to admire how well they work. The arrow keys act as your movement while Z & X are your sword and shield. You have items and skills linked to the A,S,D,F,G,Q,W,E,R,T keys which can each be rebinded. I tried to change them around but I find it much more comfortable to use the defaults. 

I definitely recommend this game to any fans of RPGs and in-game collecting.

Secrets of Grindea is a promising one in the category of early access games. It's got lovely art, good controls and a solid story that doesn't take itself too seriously. In terms of gameplay, a comparison to secret of mana seems fair: The fights are very dynamic, you can always move around freely during the fights. As your character progresses, you learn new spells and attacks which you can select with a buttons press from your quick-slots mid-fight. Attacks can also be charged. 
There is a fairly standard equipment system.
Aside of the main storyline, a lot of NPCs will ask you for help in various ways.
The strongest point of this game has to be, undoubtedly, the multiplayer support. Playing the campain with a couple of friends gives off a really well-crafted feel. The arcade-mode can also be played with friends.

The creators of the game maintain a devlog on the games homepage. So far, there is a lot of activity on there.

26837149.review:
Secrets of Grindea is very faithful to its name. The game is all about exploring, defeating enemies, leveling up your character, finding loot and, of course, grinding. There really is quite a lot of grinding if you wish to fill up your whole in-game collection.

The pixel art style is very colorful and relaxing and nostalgic to look at. A lot of work has been put into very small details.

The skills and passives in the game are not very balanced. However, most are quite fun to use and the visuals are really nice.

The game has been in early access for over a year now. I recently came back to check out the new content after a full year, and I was very happy with it. The progress of making the game is really slow, but the developers seem to take care that the content they release is very polished.

26496630.review:
TL;DR: Great game but slow progress. Recommended but see this as an investment, not a direct consumption item.

For a game that has been an on going project for this many years there are certain expacations to be made. However seeing it being an early access game made by a very small team some criticisim can be made and some can't. But that's the point of reviewing. You give critique so the creator can be better. The beauty for us gamers is that developers are like wine or whiskey. They are either good and becomes better, they are good but falls hard due to arrogance and godlike complex or they never were good to begin with. The devs of SoG are hopefully the first type.

Now enough of that and unto the game.

The graphics are smooth and fantastic, for being 2D Spirites. That is however nothing bad as they simply tap into a bit of retro or nostalgia, depending on your age. For reference it's nostalgia for me. As I started this game it felt like playing a new Zelda game. A World to explore and you as the hero. The graphics help this mindset as you travel across the land and my god is the scenery gorgeues. Even with the limited graphics of 2D spirites they make everything flow smoothly and with an almost seamless action. The particles created by the various spells and skills as well as the various stages of boss fights make this game very good. During the harder difficult I died once due to the fact that I stopped and had to process I went from a Zelda-esque game to a Touhou level bullet hell. It was beautiful

The sound and music of the game aids the nostalgic/retro feeling and the sound effects made when you cast a spell or use a skill is quite satisfying. There is no lack of audio feedback on what's going on in this game. You will know when the enemy is about to charge you or a boss is starting a massive barrage of onslought. The feedback you get as a player in this game becomes even more valuable as you play on the harder difficulty when the bosses can go from "oh look a large quantity of bullets" to "This went from casual to hardcore bullet hell real fast...."

As for the gameplay and it's mechanics I'm happy to say that it all feels fantastic. The controls respond as expected and the game runs smoothly. It lacks any need to have a beast of a machine. This is a game I have played during lunch hours on my work and those machines could be from last decade. The mechanics are well thought and well implemented into this game. It's easy to plan ahead on how you want to combat an enemy or a boss as the various types of attacks have easy and memroable patterns to learn. The fact that you also can easily switch mid-game on how you want to play makes it a nice setup for various combinations of attacks. It does however cost some money but it's worth it if you want to experiment.

The game truly makes a good claim on old grinding games. It will become a massive grindfeast if you want to. I spent a good 10+ hours farming for various cards in the game, they are used to get passive boosts. The various mechanics in how you grind with combat can go from boring to a meditative set of moves. If you enjoy grinding that is.

Overall the game works so good I really WANT the developers to finish the game but as I mentioned earlier in my TL;DR. This is to be the equivelent of a stock market investment. It may or may not yield profit in the end. Only time will tell. So far however, I've earned back my money spent in hours so for me this game was quite a good "bang for the buck" deal.

26461353.review:
If you're like me and you read game reviews before buying a game, you might be wondering why a lot of people are so massively frustrated at the lack of timely updates to this game. After playing the game, I can understand why. Secrets of Grindea is really, really good. Every single area in the game is polished to a diamond sheen. It's just a huge shame it isn't "finished".

[b]Pros[/b]
+Great Animations and Soundtrack: I really am a fan of the animations here. While the character portraits are, in my opinion, a little offputting, the animations of the characters and enemies are top-quality and show action surprisingly well. The soundtrack is very well-made and fits the areas of the game well.
+Fun Combat/Character Building: There's a lot of flexibility to the leveling system, and you don't have to fall into the Warrior/Mage/Rogue trope like many other games. The combat is fluid, and surprisingly challenging sometimes, even on normal mode.
+Surprisingly funny satire: The narrative of Secrts of Grindea plays out like a satire of genres ranging from classic Legend of Zelda-likes to MMORPGs and Roguelikes. Unlike a lot of satire, however, it does this really well. Stick with the story, and don't pass it off as another edgy attempt at satire.

[b]Cons[/b]
-Updates all over the place: From what I can see, development time is slow. You can access the beta, and the content in the beta is just as well-made as the rest of the game minus a few sound effects here and there. This, however, is not a lot of extra content, and the current beta maybe adds an hour-and-a-half to total gameplay time. I find it hard to be too critical of this considering the polish of the game, however.
-Sometimes a bit too challenging: Some areas of the game can get hard. Like, really hard. That isn't necessarily a bad thing, but due to some boss and enemy patterns, it can come down to rng more often than not. Skill will get you past it, but sometimes it can et annoying.

Overall I would suggest waiting for the game to fully release, but if you're like me and don't care too much about early-access, I would recommend it.

26409881.review:
This is a very well thought out and carefully developed game. The developers are transparent with their project and unfortunately this isn't their full time job. If you're not the type who is:

A) Interested in game design from a developer's point of view via blogs
B) Interested in providing imput and feedback on a game in development
C) Patient enough to wait as long as it may take for updates or full release

Then Secrets of Grindea may not be for you, probably best to wait for the full release because you may be disappointed. Don't get me wrong, what's been already released is great. But you'll be left wanting more, like getting a three course meal and extra long for the entree. 

Development issues aside, Secrets of Grindea is a combination of several action adventure titles, made into a unique experience. There's a lot of heavy influence from Secret of the Mana, but there's some Legend of Zelda, and Monster Hunter thrown in too, but in a way that meshes well to create something fun and engaging within itself.  

One of the best aspects is not having a class restriction. There's three skill trees: One Handed, Two-Handed, and Magic. You can focus on one, two, or a combination of three to create your own character, fully customed to your playstyle. Throw in the three passive trees: General, Melee, and Magic and you have ways to relly make skill combinations shine. So far the favorite build I've made is a Berserker that gets a magic attack bonus from less than 50% MP that randomly deals burn damage on attack and gets a physical attack bonus on burning enemies. (There are different types of support magic, but those are still in development) 

The story is engaging for what's there so far. Plenty of overused RPG tropes, but done in a humorous way that pokes fun of the genre or even some twists on what you would expect. A handful of pop culture references mixed in too for lampshading purposes. It's short, sweet, fun but still a work in progress. 

The real draw of the game is the Arcade Mode. Pretty much a Roguelike system where you run through randomly generated dungeons with whatever kind of build you want to try. This is probably where you'll be spending most of your time after "finishing" story mode. It feels like a roguelike, plays like a roguelike, and is as fun/infuriating as a rogulike. Good stuff, just make sure you go through story mode to avoid any spoilers. 

6/10 for what's on the table now. Most likely would get a 9-10/10 when fully released. Buy if you're interested, definitely follow it if you're curious. Just keep in mind that it's only three people with full time jobs making this game. Updates are pretty slow when compared to standards you may be used to with other Early Acess titles. Not a bad thing, just a lot of care put into development.

26195467.review:
优点
--优秀的像素画面风格与可爱的人物
--各种的小游戏（战斗、休闲钓鱼、竞速、射击、音游、推箱子、镜面解密等）
--各有特色的章节设计
--吸引人的收集要素
--完善的个人与任务系统

缺点
--更新速度慢如狗
--游戏内容过少

这是一部相当出色的RPG小游戏。画面整体鲜艳生动、富有活力。
游戏中有各种小游戏的系统，杂糅了各种小游戏，包括钓鱼、跑步竞速、射靶、推箱子解密，甚至还有音游。各种小游戏都和游戏的关卡结合的很紧。
不同的章节有不同的大的玩法，重复度很低，很有心意，不会厌倦。
游戏中也有很多支线任务与成就，内容重复度也不高（换句话说就是内容太少了）
但是，更新真的太慢了。一年更新2次，每次更新30min流程。不知道我能否在工作之前玩到正式版（哭）。

26192877.review:
Great game, lots of replay value (beat it 5 times), the crafting system is on point, combat feels amazing, tons of spells to use, unique monsters, really cool bosses after the first one and an overall great expirience.

Although this game excels in gameplay I don't feel very compelled by the story line, but that's probably because it's still in beta and hasn't had time to expand. So it will probably get better as the game grows.

A couple things I don't like about the game is that it doesn't allow you to fight all bosses you've beaten before, it does with certain bosses that drop loot but not with others that don't, I hope this gets changed in the near future.

Also a certain boss feels as if they aren't even a challange, the boss of which I'm talking about is [spoiler]Phaseman[/spoiler] his attacks are fair and deal enough damage but he can't sustain enough damage to make it past he's second position, he simply dies too fast, I recommend that he's health pool should be increased dramatically. So many of he's center phase attacks I did not see until my 5th playthrough.

Overall this game is pretty neato and I recomend you buy it. I currently have logged over 50 hours in offline mode on my laptop.

26156912.review:
Updated review 
It's good, I would say wait until it's FULL RELEASE to even consider buying- and before I start off this, let it be known I have nothing but love for this game and the devs themselves, they're great people, it's a great game but I need to be honest here.

The multiplayer works perfectly, I honestly couldn't detect any syncing issues which was nice. 

I feel like there should be more customization options both in character creation and skills, I know there will eventually be more skills, it's just a matter of waiting.  

The crafting system is grind heavy, I personally like that but I understand it's not for everybody. 

I feel like the combat is a little too easy once you get the hang of it although I love the enemy variety in this game and every boss can provide a bit of challenge but outside of the bosses, the game is a breeze.

The story is basically non-existent at this point but I will say the writing is charming and humorous, I actually caught myself laughing at some points. 

The updates are very infrequent and at this point and it's pissing me off, I won't hold anything back on that, since last year the story hasn't progressed in any meaningful way, I can't even bring myself to open this game anymore unless a friend asks me to play. 


Overall I give it a 3/10, I would give it a 10/10 if updates were more frequent but as a customer I'm very frustrated and frankly I'm tired of the early access game tropes.

The arcade mode is also kind of fun, forgot about that, it's kind of like binding of isaac in a small small way, pretty difficult when playing solo.

26153792.review:

As that is a lengthy process, it is going to take some time between updates, but I am into this game for the long haul. Everything it does it does with pure excellence.

If you really liked what you played so far and you have the 10 bucks to spend, I would recommend spending it on the DLC just to support the game. Being an indie developer is not easy, and these guys fucking deserve it.

26027625.review:
게임 구성된거 봐서는 업데이트와 밸런싱만 꾸준히 하면 좋을꺼 같은데, 개발이 거의 중간단계라 지금 막 사라고 추천할껀 안됨.
그래도 샀다면 어느정도 즐길거리는 있다.

아직 종류별로 만들수있는 아이템이 적고, 무기류중 하나인 완드는 게임 달성률 50% 되가는데도 제작목록에 안뜬다.
반복퀘스트도 없고, 서브퀘스트도 부족하다.

직업간 밸런스도 문제가 있다. 게임 트레일러에서는 직업경계가 없으니 섞어서 다양한 조합을 시도할수 있다고 말하지만, 한 트리만 판다. 얘네들 말로는 한손검스킬인 대쉬로 피하고 마법스킬인 파이어볼로 딜하는 상상을 할수있는데,  걍대쉬로 때리는게 편하다. (마법딜이 매우 안나오고 대쉬는 스킬 선딜과 타격까지의 시간이 매우짧은 갓-스킬이다.) 물론 섞어서 좋은 스킬이 있다지만 마나 스포 둘다 딸려서 힘들다.

이게임 마법은 거르면 된다. 일정코스트가 필요한 마법스킬과 코스트가 없는 일반평타의 딜 기대수치가 비슷하다.

그리고 전체적으로 군중제어기가 빈약하다, 하드에서 이거때문에 무진장 고통받는다. 그리고 이게임 하드는 다른 RPG에선 하드 이상이다. 

빅-도트맨이라면 사는것도 나쁘지않다.

25717120.review:
[h1]======================================[/h1]
[h1][b]Secrets of Grindea[/b][/h1] (Read on for the full review!)
[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
Secrets of Grindea is a fantastic homage to the golden age of RPGs with a lot of modern comforts mixed in. It is very much feature complete and well polished for a game in early access, and not just features relating to gameplay mechanics, but actual activities you can occupy your time with. Campaign, a roguelite arcade mode, and co-op make for a healthy bit of longevity. Presentation is great, with good graphics, animations, and sound.

Pick it up!

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Pros:[/b][/h1]
+ [b]Graphics:[/b] Clean sprites, animation, and backgrounds. Fun colorful palette.
+ [b]Audio:[/b] Music is nice, sound cues are all reasonably distinct, excluding skill sfx.
+ [b]Story:[/b] There's enough humor baked in to make it less pointless, albeit hit and miss.
+ [b]Grind:[/b] Permanent buffs through card collection, tons of items, skills, etc.
+ [b]Design:[/b] Satisfying level design, puzzles, dungeon length, progression, etc.
+ [b]Heart:[/b] Some definite love has been poured into this product.

[h1][b]Cons:[/b][/h1]
- [b]Waiting:[/b] It's not finished, yet.
- [b]Balance:[/b] Some playstyles fare better than others, but that isn't to say they aren't viable.

[h1][b]Neutral:[/b][/h1]
± [b]Binds:[/b] Controller binding slightly limited.

[h1]======================================[/h1]

[h1][b]Introduction:[/b][/h1]
Did you ever wish there was a game where you could just sit around and fish, collect, craft, fight, dungeon dive, level up, and more as you choose, with each element being satisfying, but ALSO you wanted it to be similar to games like The Oracle of Ages/Seasons in the Zelda series? Secrets of Grindea is for you! If you don't want the last aspect, go look at Stardew Valley.

[h1][b]Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
Gameplay in Secrets of Grindea is simple. Interaction and weapon/skill use are on separate keys. With a keyboard, skills can be rebinded to specific keys. With a controller, skills can be swapped out inside of specific binds, you can't change the binds for shield and weapon use. Essentially, you're either interacting with an NPC, moving around, or fighting with your weapon and skills of choice. The fun comes from how many ways there are to execute these actions.

You can fish, which involves keeping a bar lined up over an icon, horizontally. It's relaxing, satisfying, and you can even fish up equipment from time to time! You can use ingredients and even previous armors and weapons to craft new armors and weapons. Talk to NPCs for fun, or quests (many of which reward skill or talent points.) Refight bosses with ease and convenience whenever you want. Fight mobs with specific spawn zones whenever you want. Respec your build and play a different way. Redo your hair and clothes, including colors. Progress in the campaign, solving puzzles and completing challenges to complete dungeons. Kill monsters and critters to try and complete your card collection, which grant permanent buffs. Capture specific critters/monsters as pets, which can be used to boost your stats. Amass wealth by selling drops you farm. Try your builds in the roguelite arcade mode. Play alone. Play with friends. Play with strangers.

No matter who you are, I maintain there is something to like in Secrets of Grindea...

Except those annoying bees.

[h1][b]Graphics:[/b][/h1]

Oh, did I mention you can do all of this while being immersed in a cute colorful world with gorgeous sprites, backgrounds, and simple fun animations? Because you totally can do that.

The screenshots should speak for themselves.

[h1][b]Audio:[/b][/h1]

So the sound in Secrets of Grindea may be the one weak point of the game. That isn't to say it is terrible, but simply that the rest of the game is so good, it has a bit of trouble keeping up with its current implementation. You won't find yourself buried in 100 different sounds blurring together and deafening you like some games, but at the same time, the diversity of sound applied to skills and actions can be a bit unsatisfactory. If all the skills had more distinct, appealing, impactful sounds that gave them more individual identity, the game would feel a lot better, as your character would then be something more individual you can be more attached to as well. Now, all that said, you probably won't be muting the game or anything, and the music is nice, although you may end up muting that if you hang out in certain hubs a lot. On the other hand, I found myself muting the music less often than other games, because it is appropriately relaxing and/or fitting for the areas and situations they go with.

[h1][b]Conclusion:[/b][/h1]

Secrets of Grindea is an RPG about variety and freedom. Oldschool gamers, adults, kids, casuals, and hardcore players can all find something fun here. I recommend Secrets of Grindea at:

[b]Full price.[/b]
[b][i]2x Full Price.[/i][/b]
[b][i]3x Full Price.[/i][/b]
[i]Maybe even 4x Full Price.[/i]

[h1]======================================[/h1]
This endorsement approved by [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/trureviews]The Reviewers' Union[/url],
providing better standards for reviews and reviewers.
[h1]======================================[/h1]

Jugarlo sola es aburrido, dudo mucho que le echara horas si fuese un single. Ya tengo compi de coop el cual ha sido jugar como yo y enamorarse también. :3 

INSTANT BUY!

Graphically the natural areas feel genuine, there is good depth to all the environments (have a loot for the various NPCs building and repairing shit in town. Good attention to detail) and each enemy does appear to have a unique style. There are character portraits (which is awesome) and they are actually quite good with a variety of helpful emotions. All of the animations are 10/10; really satisfying to watch which really helps to promote the depth of their combat mechanics and enemy actions.

The combat system is gold. There is a variety of incredibly rewarding abilities to choose from and the devs chose a fully open point buy system with the option of point buyback at a reasonably steep cost. IT'S SO GOOD. I feel liike my decisions matter, but also that i am free to try different abilities off the list to see if i like them without being locked in forever. There are also a surprising number of ways to coordinate different abilities together so you can get fairly creative with how you build your character. 

Overall good music choices; they reinforce the tongue-in-cheek comedy with which the game explores classic RPG tropes but nevertheless they in themselves well composed and very appropriately selected. No complaints regarding sound effects. 

As you might expect the story is rather weak...then again, it's only real weakness is being predictable. Since we're following even the tropic story arcs of this games predecessors, you might expect them to seem rather generic. Again I was surprised at the amount of depth that was given each plotline within the main questline. In fact even the side-quests have a truly authentic feel to them, though mostly this is due to the lively personality of the quest-givers.

Man, the puzzles are just super, super good.

Yeah just buy this game and play it with a friend. It's really good now, and they are still adding stuff.

25473978.review:
[h1] Early Access Done Right [/h1]

There's just those few times where an early access game comes out, and it's brilliant. This is one of them. I first saw Secrets of Grindea debut on Desura, way back when. I've had my eye on the game for years as I've been skeptical of unfinished indie titles. Now a friend and I own Secrets of Grindea and it's [i]fantastic[/i]. It's everything a good RPG needs and it's not even finished yet. Here are some points.

[h1] PROS [/h1]
[list]
[*]Fantastic, and I mean absolutely [b]extraordinary[/b] pixel graphics. Some areas completely blew my mind because of how wonderful the scenery looked.
[*]Expertly crafted levels give a smooth feel to the game. The plains in the beginning felt chaotic. Felt like it had a sense of wildlife. The town had a clever building layout, the [spoiler]flying fortress[/spoiler] felt symmetric and not too maze like. The [spoiler]Halloween[/spoiler] map had a wonderful border effect, winding and narrow paths and perfect but not too difficult maze-like structure.
[*]Upbeat and catchy soundtrack deserving of it's own DLC.
[*]Excellent, sometimes halarious sidequests keep the player engaged every time a main story plot was advanced through.
[*]Mindboggling puzzles and secrets that make you think in order to get the reward rather than have you kill a generic miniboss (While minibosses are a thing in the game, they are rare and require some skills to take out.)
[*]Up to 4 player supported co-op that really shines. The main story has subtle changes to accomodate to a party with the host being considered the 'main character' while the others were his equally as powerful and important friends.
[*]Competetive or Uncompetitive loot share allows for a race-to-the-loot type of co-op gameplay or a relaxed type of co-op gameplay where everyone gets the same items from chests but generic enemy loot drops are split randomly throughout the group so that everyone get's a slice of the bloodied pie.
[*]Extensive skill system and trees allowed for all types of gameplay with no class restrictions. Be a Claymore weilding mage, or a Duelist that uses both a Sword and Shield and Two-Handed. Become a jack-of-all-trades with the 4 magic types (Fire, Air, Water, Earth) and a master of none.
[*]Ingenious inventory system allows for both and equipment and vanity slots and also allows you the ability to 'transmog' your equipment such as wands, swords, and shields to look like previously collected weapons without the sacrifice in stats. Same goes for armor.
[*]You can have a smiling cloud that craps lightning on your foes.
[/list]

[h1] CONS [/h1]
[list]
[*]With up to 4 player co-op, the screen can end up having a lot going on in one small space. This is especially true in some small boss arenas like the [spoiler]GUN-DAM[/spoiler] fight where you have to really pay attention to where you're going. While also making sure you and your friends stay out of harms way.
[*]In some areas like the [spoiler]Halloween Forest[/spoiler], a lot of enemies can be in the same areas at once. This can make solo-play challenging especially as enemies respawn on a seemingly short respawn timer that can make battles turn hairy at a moments notice.
[*]The mix of magic, skills, basic attacks, and enviornmental awareness can sometimes really disorient people. It's difficult to fight multiple small enemies at once while also keeping an eye on your remaining energy, switching between normal and special attacks, blocking with your shield, AND keeping an eye on your shield-block meter. This sort of combat inspires a rushed and adrenaline-fueld high octane battle enviornment giving people a rush to smash their keys as quickly as possible. At least that's what happens with me. And this usually ends up with me not noticing my health dropping or my friend ending up dead right next to me.
[*]The crafting system is intuitive and mysterious, with some recipies not being able to be unlocked until you find a certain item from a dropped creature. For example, the icon for Honey was greyed out until I managed to kill a bee and get myself one unit of Honey. Along with this, the item your crafting tells you the stats OF the item BEFORE you make it, just so you don't accidentally make something you can't use. Why is this a flaw? Well this isn't a flaw in itself, the flaw comes from the process of MAKING the item. For example, to make an Apple Hat I had to take a Straw Hat and gather [b]60, count 'em, SIXTY APPLES[/b]. This can make the game feel grindy, no pun intended. I'm not exactly sure if that's an intended feature or not, but it's not a huge problem since crafting isn't the main focus of the game, and more likely a menu you will look through every-so-often just to check if you gathered enough items to fill a certain criteria.
[/list]

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]
That's pretty much it. I think this may be the longest review I've ever written, but I think SoG deserves it. At the time of writing this, I'm only 2 hours into the game and I can't wait to see what I can uncover next. This is truly an amazing RPG/Adventure game.

I will update the review throughout the early access process and with my advancement of the game. Thank you for giving the time to read this review, and I'll see you in Grindea.

25362684.review:
Absolutely fantastic. I mean that, Best $15 I've spent in a good while.

This developer earned my appreciation in a lot of ways in just 30 minutes. First, There is a free demo of the game. You can actually see, first hand, whether the game is going to run properly on your machine without spending a dime. Second, The game warns you of an error that makes some pcs run fullscreen mode badly in the demo. I do not experience this error, I find that it runs perfectly in fullscreen on my (rather old) pc. But the fact that they make that apparent in the demo shows an amount of respect for your time and money that, as a games consumer, I'm well accustomed to not getting. Third, The actual content of the game:

Take the 2D Zelda titles, Update the pixel art quality, Add in Diablo-inspired skill trees, but hold the class restrictions. Then add active blocking with a timing mechanic that makes a perfectly timed block benefit you in some way, Differently depending on the attack being blocked. Then vary the weapons, One handed weapons for a swift attacking mobile build, Two handed for a slower hard-hitter, passive buffs on weapons for builds with other sources of damage. Then add spells; Simple fireballs, ice spikes, and chain lightning for damage. Utility spells like haste and damage buffs, Summons to support you, Debuffs to slow or continually damage enemies, and (Being a game in beta) More to come.

Then there are the little things:

*Pressing a key on your keyboard will change the control prompts to keyboard keys, Pressing a button on your controller will turn them into controller versions. No need to fiddle around with the options, It's automatic.

*Downloading the demo before buying the game completes some of the full download, Reducing the time the download takes and minimizing redundant data use. 

*Your save files from the demo will be carried over to the full game should you (And you should) Purchase it.

*And a tongue-in-cheek sense of humor present throughout that amuses me while not taking me out of the experience.


I look very much forward to this game's future development and eventual completion, and to whatever Pixel Ferrets decides to do after. With the clear high standard of quality and respect for their customers they display I have no doubt in my mind that it will satisfy.

25248102.review:
I played the demo through, sat on it for a day, and decided I absolutely should buy the game.  It seems inspired by games like Link to the Past (one of my favourites) and has a similar feel to it.  I like that there is a lot of depth to characters, though if you go for a plain 1h or 2h fighter you'll probably end up with a sort of samey character as you level up all of the 1h or 2h skills.  That said, there are tons of options for combinations with various kinds of magic and skills, though I would like if leveling up skills had more of an effect than 1-2% at a time for most of them, to further increase character diversity.

The depth is very good in that there is a lot to do with your character, but not in a confusing way.  I was surprised when I found out you can also level up pet skills to further increase stats, and collecting monster cards also gives solid bonuses.  Looking back, it doesn't seem very complicated now that I've played through the current game a couple times, because it's easy to understand.  If you want to play through the game just mashing the attack button, that's fine (it will be really hard though), but you also have the option to level your skills in such a way that you can set up crazy combos and blow everything up.  The combat later on gets exciting enough that it's fun even to grind mobs looking for the card drop, both against the easy mobs and hard ones.

If you like the demo, and are willing to pay for a promising early access game, I recommend it.  The game feels very polished, it's just a tad short at the moment (~8-10h to get through the story mode)

25240588.review:
Many reviews note that this game is a ripoff and has slow development. And frankly, yeah, it's been in development forever. There is a dev blog and it is updated fairly often but there is still a lack of justification for the length of time it's taken to complete the game.

That aside, this is not like other early access games. This is a really, really well-made game with a lot of content already in it. There is clearly a lot of love that went into this game down to the sprite animations, the little cutscenes, puzzles, and gameplay itself. I went through the main portion of the content in 15 hours and beyond that there's achievements and arcade mode which is insidious and takes forever. Co-op is really fun and unique especially considering most games don't offer it, ever.

This was without a doubt worth the $15 even unfinished. I loved playing this game and I was instantly addicted. It's extremely refreshing to see quality of this magnitude with indie development. And yet, what's disappointing is the lack of additions in such a length of time. This game has a colossal amount of potential to be even more than it is right now. 

If you're okay with 50% of a game and 10-15 hours of gameplay, you won't regret purchasing it.

25218921.review:
Apparently, from what I've been told and read, that this game has been in development for 5 years.

I come back to the game a year after I beat the content of the game and all that's been added is a few pages of dialogue and a new "dungeon". Took me about an hour or so to bust through the new additions, then I spent some time in arcade mode.

So... Let's do some simple maths ('Cause I don't know how to do much else concerning maths);

~1 hour of story content = 1 year of development.

Game looks to be about 30-50% "complete" in its story. Wouldn't be surprised if the devs skimped a bit just to release a "full product" in a few years.

Let's take a look at, say Cave Story. Took a guy 5 years (during his spare time, also in college and working a full time job) to make this game. Game's a masterpiece in its genre. Polished and perfected.

Let's also assume that the 3 devs (I dunno if they hired anyone else, doubt it though) are also on this same schedule. Spare time working on the game only. 5 x 365 = 1826. 1826 / 3 = 608.733333~

That's just shy of 2 years in development for a completely finished product if 3 people are on the workload in an an equal capacity. So why has it taken 3 people 5 years to do the same amount of work as 1 guy? Why is the development of this game so slow and awful?

I shall pose an answer for you in the form of a question; Say you pay someone upfront, the full price of the cost to put a roof on your house. What is the motivation to actually do the work? What's stopping this company from driving in a single nail per day and then calling it quits? They already have your money, why continue with the job at all?

Early Access is just... A bad business model in its current form. It's not bad for the business, that's for sure, as games like Starbound and this one will attest to. It's bad for the consumer, and for some reason the consumer just laps this garbage up like it's some sort of ambrosian nectar of the dev-gods. There really needs to be some sort of time-limit (One year at the most, 30 days after the deadline to clean up) for games to either finish their development and release a full product, or start refunding all purchases completely.

As it stands, there's absolutely no reason for anyone to ever pull "Early Access Game" from their pages it's basically free money for a tech demo and a couple of lines of "story" to sate the spasms of frothing, ADD-rattled fans.

Gaming has fallen so far, and I hope for another crash.

This is one of the best games I've ever played. And it's not even finished. 

No wonder it's taken so long for the small (3 person) team to develop. Every inch of this game is beautifully designed and animated. The dialogue is fresh and interesting, and actually funny! The combat system is fun and allows for a surprisingly deep amount of customization and specialization particularly in coop play. The monsters are all unique and have well-designed AI and combat patterns. 

The story and the world is the best part. It's completely immersive, colorful, and filled with life. Very few games, even AAA open world titles, create a world that you want to explore as much as Grindea. A sense of adventure is in the air. One thing is clear. The developers have made this game with LOVE.

To any old Maplestory players: buy this game and when you finish it you'll have TWO games that will physically pain you to remember because nothing will ever feel the same.

25190055.review:
8/10
A solid game, considering as of August 2016 it's in Early Access. What do you get for 10.99? You get a modern retro looking rpg clearly inspired by the SNES era, with the option to play solo or with up to 3 friends with either keyboard or controller (I recommend you use controller). The gameplay is captivating: the boss battles especially are well crafted and not to mention very challenging. These battles do a good job of incorporating the co-op aspect although the battles are almost as fun solo, albeit slightly easier.
The world has a variety of locations and each is unique both in visuals and inhabitants. The music and sound effects are excellent. The story is funny in parts but not the main attraction. Where the game really shines is with its weapon and class systems. There are lots of attacks to use whilst in combat using a range of melee weapons, magic and specials. The game constantly allows you to level up skills and gain new ones. Like in most games from this genre, you have the choice on which skills you'd like to focus on more, for example making your character's health high so you can act more as a tank, rushing into swarms of enemies whilst a friend attacks from afar with magic or a bow. Improving your attacks is rewarding and, in my opinion, is one of the most enjoyable aspects about Secrets of Grindea. 
Quests involve puzzles, exploration and quite a bit of reading (obviously, although cutscenes can be skipped). Overall it is a great game that is easily woth its price. 
The only negatives would be: it has a mediocre story and missed the oportunity to make pets aid your character in battle (instead they just follow you around and that's it).

24923633.review:
Secrets of Grindea.  It's the love letter to old RPGs, a look and feel of games that hasn't been felt since the 16-bit era of video games.  Sure, there have been many, MANY 16-bit games in the modern day and age that have held the title of "RPG", but one not done so in the vein of Grindea.

Pros:
+ Very fluid combat
+ A decent amount of melee/magic skills to use for any custom build you want!
+ Music is cheery and lighthearted; it's no OST like Nier: Automata, but Grindea's OST is... oddly satisfying
+ GRINDING
+ Collectable cards that give passive bonuses that drop randomly when farming enemies
+ You can build a house!
+ The puns in this game are excellent
+ Very easy game to get into
+ Co-op!
+ LoZ-esque puzzles

Cons:
- Not so much a dealbreaker, BUT the content is slow coming.  NOTE: the dev team is made up of three people, so be patient!
- Boss battles were designed to be beat in one go; meaning you have no health potions you can buy, but can pick up health orbs that will keep you in the fight

1998/1998: would Grind and feel nostaligc about RPGs all over again

É um jogo sensacional, com uma história bem envolvente e personagens carismáticos.

O jogo tem a pegada de Zelda, principalmente nos calabouços, e também te dá elementos de outros jogos de RPG como uma árvore de talentos onde ela pode ser mesclada da forma que quiser (o que torna a variação de personagens muito interessante).

24623862.review:
Before you buy this game, there are large portions of the game not finished, if you intend to complete the game; wait on this.

I completed my first run through on normal in about 4-6 hours. I'm not playing through on Hard, which by the way is really hard for those who enjoy a solid challenge mode.

If you enjoyed games such as Secret of Mana, Legend of Zelda LTTP, and Diablo 2, this game might be for you. The combat works like the former games while the character builder works more like an action RPG. With a large variety of spells and melee abilities, part of the fun of this game is working on builds and seeing which ones work and which fail miserably.

The shining point of this game is the combat and character building, so if you enjoy those things you might consider a purchase.

The story is solid, the comical parts are funny, and you get just the right amount of information so that the cutscenes (which are all skippable) aren't too long, nor are you confused as to why you're doing something.

The puzzles I've found hard rather difficult late in the game, practically one that requires you to build a bridge, with a limited amount of pieces, to cross the room. The crossing of the room is rather easy, figuring out how to get the extra item however is a real challenge that took quite a while to figure out.

The boss designs are good too. With solid boss mechanics that are hard to the point where when you first face a boss you think “how is this possible?” But then is really satisfying once you complete it. 

Really this game has few flaws besides not being completed. Once it is done, it could easily be one of the best Action RPGs ever.

Secrets of Grindea is a pixel based game with great story. If your looking for a game with great story and lots of cutomization this game is great. This game is however not fully finished so the story isnt complete however i think this makes the game more enjoyable for me as im able to watch the game progress and get better. If you dont enjoy the campaign you can try arcade mode which tests your fighting going through room after room of mobs, each with a boss room at the end of each floor. The game has a diverse range of boss fights from a giant robot to a three headed hydra. Although you may think the combat wouldnt be challenging your wrong as there is perfect blocking which allows your shield durability to not drop this can be extremly challenging to master

In the end i would highly reccommend this game to anyone wanting something retro or even just a fun game to play. I would rate this game a 8/10.

How this game is currently

1. Hit things till they die with weapons and/or magic
2. Take their items and money
3. Make stuff with those items
4. Do the occasional Quest
5. Fight the occasional boss
6. Fight those bosses till you get their items
7. Fish for six hours
8. Kill everything until you get their card

This is why people might like or dislike this game but if you can't tell that there's grinding in this game you probably don't have a proper vocabulary

Interested? Read This First!

Content
It really depends on how you play it. I lke to call myself a beta tester even though im not and i dedicated my time to try and collect all items. Still havent done it though and ive put nearly 50 hours into the game. If you are a person who likes to collect things, try to find interesting exploits and glitches, then the game is perfect for you if you put it on frontline. If you are a hardcore speed runner, the game is still good for you even if it isnt on frontline as the arcade mode has infinate replay value and you could try and give yourself a challenge by putting the story mode on hardmode. However if you are a person that gets disinterested in things very quickly, this game is fun but not the best for you.

If you put the game on frontline you will get very frequent game changes, update ideas, bug fixes, and other things that will have you able to play the game over and over to see what they changes and how it affects the game. For regular/non-frontline updates, you will see updates every so often, sometimes quicker than you think, but not as frequent as frontliners.

Max level
There isnt a max level and i would know becuase most are levels 30-40 while im level 35000 something. No joke.

If you need any more info on the game just send me a message.

23863353.review:
In terms of other games: imagine Secret of Mana, with a structure that lets you just hop in and play with your friends, in a lighthearted Ragnarok Online setting.

Secrets of Grindea is a smooth, charming 2D hack and slash with cute enemies and a fun world to explore that doesn't take itself too seriously. Fighting mobs of enemies feels great, and there are some cool bosses. Quests and areas are easy to understand without being too straightforward. The structure is pretty linear but offers some fun diversions in the form of collectible items, crafting recipes, and short side quests. Cooperative play is well-implemented in terms of interface and networking code, but doesn't really require you to specialize your characters to fight as a team. Overall, it's fun! It's like snack food (something familiar to satisfy a craving) but it's well-made, crisp, cheesy snack food.

23740146.review:
El juego es bueno, de eso no hay duda, pero tiene sus fallos, empezando por el de que esto está aún en desarrollo, uno muy lento he de decir.

En si, el juego tiene dos modos:

-Modo historia: Es simplemente eso, como en un RPG vas haciendo misiones y vas desbloqueando areas, items, etc... La historia en si gira en torno al farmeo propio de estos juegos, eres un recolector (literalmente, estás en un grupo de recolectores que viajan por el mundo recogiendo artefactos antiguos), no es nada del otro mundo, pero vas viendo y conociendo la mitologia e historia del mundo en el que te encuentras. Los bosses son muy dinamicos y muy estilo bullet hell, te lanzan cientos de ataques y tú los esquivas (o bloqueas). En si es un mundo muy colorido, con personajes y enemigos no muy originales, pero tiene su propio carácter.

-Modo arcade: es un rogue like, sencilla y planamente. Tu vas de planta en planta limpiando todas las salas de enemigos hasta llegar a un boss y subir a la siguiente planta. El elemento más diferenciador de esto pueden ser las misiones que te dan algunos NPCs que van apareciendo según más puntos acumulas y un sistema con el que puedes conseguir enfocarte en una clase al empezar el recorrido, como empezar con un mejor escudo, con mas vida, una espada de verdad o un bastón de mago entre muchas otras. Lo mejor de esto es el multijugador online, te conectas con amigos y te pones a repartir mamporros a diestro y siniestro. Por otro lado, la única manera de curarte es en la primera sala al llegar a la siguiente planta, si has tenido la suerte de llegar sin sufrir daño te darán una poció de curación para que la uses cuando quieras, pero ya está.

El sistema de combate recuerda mucho a los Zelda de Game Boy Advance, solo que aquí hay clases e incluso puedes combinar ataques de espada con magia, lo cual resulta muy útil, o especializarte solamente en una rama. Los escudos tienen barra de aguante para que no estés abusando de inmunidad, pero también tienen sus propias mecánicas, como la capacidad de darte críticos.

De por si el juego no es ninguna revolución, pero las cosas que hace en las mecánicas de pelea las hace muy bien, sin embargo el lento desarrollo ha hecho que tenga un modo historia incompleto además de lo frustrante que se vuelve en si al pasar las cinco plantas en el modo arcade. En estos momentos este juego vale sobre todo para jugar con amigos, pero no pagaría los 14 euros que cuesta, si encontrais un pack de cuatro en humble bundle o algo parecido, intentad aprovecharlo con otros tres amigos, saldrá más a cuenta. A pesar del lento desarrollo, el juego sigue teniendo actualizaciones, pero puede llevar tres o cuatro años más para que esté completo. Si lo pillais de rebajas mejor.

23645471.review:
[h1]My God.[/h1]
I don't know how to praise this game enough. I was skeptical about picking this one up, but after 9 hours of non-stop playing, I can say that this is one of my favourite games of all time. There are so many skills to choose from, but since you can un-spend skill points for only a little gold, you can try out different combos without ruining your character. The two-handed melee skills are absolutely amazing and make you feel like you're ripping your enemies to shreds. One of the skills is literally batting enemies into other enemies, making them explode in a chain reaction of gold and slime goop.

A word of warning for those who don't get it: [i]Grind[/i]ea. You're going to be grinding at some point or another, but since enemies constantly respawn and pile onto your slowly dying character, even farming is ridiculously fun for the majority of items. For the rarer creatures, it's less fun and less quick, but as all enemies reset when you leave and enter a room, it shouldn't be too bad.

23645304.review:
Combat is very fluid and deep. Different skills can completely change how you fight, and you can pretty easily re-spec to try out other builds if you like. Fighting isn't a mash of pixels like bullet hell games. While it's a bit faster than something like Secret of Mana it still relies on skill and handling timing.

The graphics are much better than others you'll find on steam (like, wanderlust for instance) and work at large resolutions.  

Controller support isn't the best, but using something like joy2key works fine.

There are two bad parts of the game:

1.) Windows only. Linux/OSX support would be nice. This is extremely unlikely to ever happen based on how slow development has been for really simple things.

2.) Lack of story content. While there is a fair amount of side things to do, the story is comically short for as long as it has been in development, and updates have been at best slow to come. In the last 2.5 years, there is basically one new dungeon, which is a short one. 

I still doubt that this game will ever be "finished" in a worthy state, but its worth at the very least checking out the demo.

This game is absolutly worth the purchase.

My wife and I love playing it co-op.  She is not the best gamer, however the controls and interface a suitably accessable.

23303256.review:
Secrets of Grindea.....how do I say this in a way that people will think, "Wow, this games sounds good, I should play this?" Well I don't know honestly. But I'll try my best!

Okay so here we go! Secrets of Grindea, first look before buying it I though to myself, "Eh, this games doesn't look too bad. I hope it's not like every other rpg I've played." So I bought this game knowing that it was still early access. What a gamble! 

Okay now lets talk about my first reaction.I booted up the game, (do people even say that anymore?) and was welcomed by a nice and catchy theme song, one I still cannot get out of my head. I proceeded to select stroymode, singlplayer and boom I was in the game! I played through the intro, the first boss, the second boss, and the first two areas. I fell in love with the game because it was really unique and interesting, let's not forget about fun!

Fighting! The combat is smooth and not boring, plus the cartoonish style makes it enjoyable. Two handed swords are slow, one handed swords are fast like they should be and wands make magic dealy but don't hurt much. The skills they have add a sort of customization to the game that can make a player speicalize in what they want wether its a tank role,  supportrole, or somwhere in between. Magic in the game is fun though some of the schools of magic,which are ground, wind, ice, and fire, are better than the other this can lead to a broken system where one school of magic in the game is never used making it pointless. 

Another great feature of the game is the pets! You got to love the pets they're soo CUTE!!! *cough* *cough* On a professional note pets are a fun feature that really adds to the game. The best part of the pets is  that you can feed them certain items that boost your overall stats. This is great like I said previously but broken becuase the game itself has no protection against hacking. You could hack in a billion speed potions if you wanted to and feed them to your pet which makes you OP as heck and can ruin the gaming experience.

Lets talk about the gameplay, so far in the game at the date this is written you can only play the game up to Mt.Bloom, which is okay because the game is still in EARLY ACCESS. The monsters can be challenging at times and make you upset. I don't know how many I died by a monster and said," I am going to destroy your face!" I am looking at you Halloweed. The leveling system is pretty fair with a great exp rate through out the story. The bosses are nice with a unique challenge for all of them, you have to create tactics and learn the bosses attack patterns before you can triumph over them. WARNING: Prepare to get creamed by some bosses!! The level spikes in each area you go to are mostly appropriate besides the third area which can get a tad tough becuase of certain enemies. ( I swear the Yeti species hate me >.> )

What is an RPG without multiplayer, am I right? Secrets of Grindea goes about there Co-op experience just fine. You can play story mode with friends or play Arcade mode with friends. There is no match making feature currently in the game so you have to go make some friends to play multiplayer. During the story mode when you play multi player whoever is the host of the game it's their story, so don't expect to pick up where you left off in the story mode with your friends if you try to play solo. When you play solo it is your own story on the specific character. The Arcade mode is where you traverse through floors trying to make it to the end, if you die you start all over and loose your gear. There is a warning though, this mode could potentially ruin the story line.

Overall this game is really fun and I reccommend that eveyone gives it a try. I rate this game, IN ITS CURRENT STATE AS OF 6/26/2016,  8.5/10 Paws

不过《格兰蒂亚秘闻》中的要素更多，包括技能加点、卡片系统、装备制作等等。

游戏也支持4人联机，包括故事模式和街机模式两种，而且似乎也是本地主机，反正同一地域网络联机应该不会卡的。

23255747.review:
Possibly one of my favorite games ever. Sunk in almost 20 hours as of writing this.
ᴮᵉᵉᶰ ᶰᵉᵍᶫᵉᶜᵗᶦᶰᵍ ᵒᵛᵉʳʷᵃᵗᶜʰ ᶠᵒʳ ᵗʰᶦˢ

Secrets of Grindea has kept my attention from the start. I had played the demo and been hyped as ever for this. Completed the current story as of build .650a and have been working on achievements as well. Currently the story isn't SUPER long. But if you don't try and rush the whole thing and take your time as well as take in the atomosphere of the game, I believe you'll really enjoy it. I spent most of my time GRINDING for cards and item drops, still missing that damn rabbits foot.
On the topic of Grinding, this game has LOADS of it. But oddly enough I enjoy the grind, you feel satisfaction when you finally acquire the item you've been busting your arse trying to obtain.

To sum up my feelings about this game. It has AMAZING potential, and I hope to be along for the entire ride as the game develops. I also really hope I have some friends that will buy this soon as it can get lonely on your own all the time. Especially when you don't have meatshields for arcade.

23093601.review:
A meal in one long "taste test" session, but unlike Delver, it still appears to hold promise of completion.
But I will review it as is, anyway.
What can I say? It gives off a smell that reminds you of your younger days, mixed in with a smell that promises freedom.
When you take a bite, it's not bad at all. Although its name is related to the exercise of "Grinding" in most RPGs and it makes references to it, you'll be grinding the night away, with it's systems designed to make grinding less of a chore.
You can also choose to challenge yourself in the "Hard" mode. This mode will make you suffer, but you will also feel much more rewarded afterwards, the taste of victory oh so sweeter.
There's also an arcade mode, a delve into a more "arcade-y" meal. You've only got one life and you have to make it as far as possible. It also gives rewards to the main story, if you want an excuse to taste this mode.

23051178.review:
Быстрый обзор. 
+ Интересный сюжет (хоть порой и банален до предела)
+ Наличие хорошего юмора
+ Говорящий мешок
+ Стилистика игры
+ - Некоторые босы могут проплавить стул под вами. 
- + Система боя постоянно нужно выбирать правильное направление. (в игре нет мышки), немножко топорная.
- Большое количество однотипных головоломок. (пока встречал только элементарные и всё что они делают это просто тормозят прохождение)
- Однотипные квестовые локации (не все) по принципу сходи переключи влево, сходи переключи прямо, бос. Тадааам.
P/S Все относиться только к режиму истории аркадный не тестил. Но в любом случае игра стоит своих денег. 
9 горящих пуканов из 10
Нет серьезно некоторые босы это ....ц
Редактирую мнение спустя еще пару часов игры, кто придумал задачки на тайминг, знай ты плохой человек. Просто нет слов.
33 сгоревших пукана из 10

Yes

Not Reallu\y

22929719.review:
Let me qualify here, I like this game quite a bit and I think it does deserve all the praise it recieved. So why the negative review? Well for one, Steam doesn't give me the option to have a neutral review, and two I want to give potential buyers some reasons as to why they wouldn't want to buy in. Most of the negative reviews don't really do that, at least not in detail.

I've been following this game for a long time, a lot of love has gone in to its development, and it really shows through the quirky spritework. The problem with the development is that it's just been so painfully slow that I can't recommend spending $15 on it at this point, because the desire to check back in after a few months when nearly nothing new has been added fades away after over two years; and that's how long I've had this game. It was first released for beta purchase around April 1, 2014.

Over the course of two years, the story has essentially gained one new dungeon (of which there was only one before) along with a marginal amount of content that shows this game is going to be in development for many more years. The content that's there is good, sure, but it's not so stellar as to justify playing through the story more than once or twice.

The real mode that seems to add playtime to this game is its arcade mode, which is roguelike in nature, and requires a good understanding of enemy/boss patterns to do well in. Players play through two floors representing each area in the story mode, complete with enemies from said area, and have no chances to heal except at the end of each floor. Despite having numerous floors and all of the enemies from the story mode, it's pretty light on content in terms of roguelikes. There are unlockables and such, but they only give minor advantages, and as a result adding more floors to the mode seems kind of pointless in its current state. Even after over two years of going back to this game I struggle to reach the 7th floor of what must be over 14 at this point. There isn't much incentive to bother trying to reach those floors either. 

So should you buy this game? Well that depends on how patient you are. After two years I'm pretty burned out and don't see myself playing this game for a long, long time. If you think you can wait for what could be 5 years to play a finished product and want to support the developers, then by all means get this game. If not, keep an eye on it and pick it up a few years down the road when it has a more justifiable amount of content to offer.

Edit: Thanks for all the support guys, since this review got so much attention I want to add a little more. 

If you're worried about spending $15 on a game that won't be finished, don't be. This game is a safe buy in my opinion. Even though the development has been very slow, it has been extremely consistent and the team behind this game definitely has what it takes to finish the job. Secrets of Grindea has been in the works since 2011, and the quality of the content in it has only improved since. Their [url=http://www.secretsofgrindea.com/index.php/dev-blog]dev blog[/url] has a weekly recap that is posted nearly every week without missing a beat. So if you're interested, definitely keep an eye on this game, because it is one of the better early access titles out there, despite the slow development speed.

22918271.review:
This game needs quite a bit of tweaking. 
After only 2 and a half hours of gameplay, not only have I had to restart the game from the begining, but I would have to do it again because half of the quests I do break if I exit and save only to come back the next day and find out that I apparentley I already did it even though the quest is still not done.
Another issue I encountered was that when I saved on my first session playing this game and came back the next day, even though I had all my equipment, all of my quest and story progress had been lost. Pretty annoying if you ask me.
My third and final issue that I found was that half the time while trying to run the game, instead of loading it up straight away like my other games, it wouldn't start up. So after clicking on the desktop icon a couple times, it finally loaded up but not properly. The game's resolution screwed up my screen size and zoomed in on a portion of my desktop in a lower quality without the game even loadind up fully. The taskbar icon for the game was active but the game itself wasn't running at all. It didn't even come up when I loaded task manager and tried to end task it. Manually closing it from the taskbar didn't help either. I tried to get a refund, but of course you can only get a refund for a game if you have UNDER 2 HOURS. Pretty dissapointed because not only could I have spent my hard earned cash on something else that would actually work, but I can't even get my money back.
Overall, gameplay and fighting is kinda generic and well put together, but the amount of bugs in only 2 and a half hours is pretty horrendous.
4/10

P.S. The resolution screwing up when booting up the game may be just my fault because of the small resolution monitor that I play on, but come on:
It's a laptop

22910808.review:
After 20+ hours i can confidently say this game has me hooked. So far only played single player and am really enjoying it. The story and characters are rather cute and funny which is a nice change of pace from new age games and quite reminiscent of an old school RPG atmsophere. The puzzles are also well done. There was a few moments in the in the Fae forest that were top notch and had me thinking the whole time going in between back and forth desperately trying to figure out what to do. The combat is also very enjoyable. Very rarely can you just "go ham" and often you have to think before attacking. Boss fights actually being a challenge and needing strategy is a huge deal to me. AS for a score not sure what i grade it its good but i dont know if its that good. If this game gets some more content a littel more balancing and some final polish 10/10 easy. As is, I have to rate it a 7/10 due to lack of content and a few balancing issues, If they fill out that support tree make that a 8/10 (biased mage player here XD). Support is a staple to co-op play in any game so it will be nice to see what they will add. I must say i dont know how a healer or heal skills would be implemented but it would be nice for someone to be able to play "Team Mom" keeping everyone healthy and buffed. Maybe a regen over time heal or something. 
So my final call if u dont mind spendning the money and it looks decent to you then by all means go ahead. Its fun, but short, yet retains a very unique style you won't find elsewhere. As someone playing the game atm my final call is please go buy and help them finsh the game. It is truly a masterpiece just in need of some more content. If you really enjoy the game remember theres a hat dlc you can buy to help support the devs as well.

Herkese Selam.
        Öncelikle söyleyeyim, bu oyun sadece triple a oynayan ve başka oyun bilmeyen; veya sadece League of Legends ve Counter Strike gibi popüler oyun oynayan tiplerin bilmediği, bilmemesi gereken benim has oyuncu kitlesi olarak tanımladığım tipler arasında kalmasını düşündüğüm bir oyun.
        Oyun, Startington adlı köyde başlıyor ve basit çiflik görevleriyle oyuna ısındırıyor. Ama emin olun oyun bundan fazlası.
Oyunda farklı farklı bolgeler var. Bunların kimi bir şehir kimi mistik bir orman. Ve bahsettiğim bölgelerin hepsi de atmosferik açıdan bir şaheser.Bu bölgelerin içinde farklı diyaloglar farklı görevler veya hiçbir oyunda bulamadığım zevkte boss savaşları var. Boss savaşları oyuna ayrı bir zevk veriyor çünkü yeni neslin ''MUHTEŞEM'' diye tanımladığı aaa oyunların hepsinde boss savaşları tekdüze. Yani vur kaç. Bossların hepsi farklı, hepsinin farklı bir taktiği var bu oyunda.
        Oyundaki savaş tarzı oldukça zevki ve öğrenmesi basit. Bir kılıç ve kalkanla başlıyorsunuz. Oyun ilerledikçe elinize geçen farklı silahlara farklı stratejiler geliştiriyorsunuz. Farklı büyüler öğrenebiliyorsunuz.
        Bu savaş sadece bosslar için değil elbette. Fragmandada gördüğünüz üzere açık dünya bir oyun. İlk başta bahsettiğim farklı bölgelerde farklı yaratıklar var. Bunların hepsinin de ayrı zayıf noktaları...
        Bu oyunun kilit noktası ise co-op olarak oynanabilmesi 1-4 kişi arası oynanabilir olması onu rakiplerinden daha güçlü kılıyor. Bu oyuna çok benzer olan Stardew Walley'de bu özellik yok. Bu yüzden Grindea'yı tercih ettim.
        Hikaye açısındanda diğerlerinden geri kalır bir yönü yok. Gayet zevkli. Zindanlar tapınaklar çiftlikler hikayeye ve oynanışa tat katıyor. Son olarak babamızın eski dostu çanta var. Oyun esnasında kesinlikle dikkate almanız gereken bir karakter. Özellikle de ölünce (benden tavsiye)
Hikaye 6/10
Oynanış 9/10
Görsellik 9/10
RPG Elementleri 9/10
Puanım: 8/10

22744640.review:
When I first saw this game I thought it was some JRPG a game focused on story with little gameplay but it would make up for that with how extensive the customization is. I figured 17.00$ for a unfinished game might not be worth it even if it is good because it is still in early access and would have so little to the game that it is not worth it. The game looked like a higher quality indie maker game and that was not what I was interested in so I dismissed it. I wanted something that will have lots to do good gameplay and lots of replay value. 

I was really wrong about the game. It is so good it is a contender to be one of my favorite games of all time. The game has great replay value, online multilayer, great combat, the fishing mini game is actually okay and it has a interesting but overall funny story that is skipable.  

This game have great replay value there are many different monsters that can drop up to 4 different items when you defeat them, some are crafting items sometimes you can get some armor, a sword or a shield. Sometimes you need to gather crafting items to craft a new item or you can just find a new hat, sword if you kill enough monster that drop items. You can play the game with 4 players making the game harder the more people that play but the game is still fun to play because you can spend time focusing on collecting all the items in the game. I have almost played the game over 24 hours and I still have not gathered all the items, cards, achievement and even finished the story. You can change the game from easy to hard in the middle of the game making it very fair. The game has replay value because you could replay the game to have a magic user build otr a melee user build or something like that. 

The gameplay is fun there is normal and hard difficulty hard adds a few more monsters to the levels makes them more aggressive, faster and stronger. The magic in the game is fair and not overpowered like it is in other games. You have powerful magic but summoning a monster reduces your energy while your summoned monster or passive spells is out. When you level up your base stats go up and if you want extra challenge you could play the game without leveling up and for a price you can respend your points on new spells and abilities. The game does something crazy it makes it fun and gives you a reason to kill over 1000 slimes. You would want to kill the slimes for exp, money, collectibles, cards, crafting items, and even if you already have these you can sell them for money and give them to other players. And the best part is killing slimes is fun they get smarter the more you kill and if your not careful even easy monsters can hurt you.    

The story is great it is funny, full of references to games like legend of Zelda other games anime movies etc. The story is interesting enough to watch a few times but thankfully you can skip it if this is your 20th time playing the game. 

The game has fair DLC there is a 5 dollar hat DLC that is honest that if you play 5 dollars you will give the devs more money so if you want to support them you can. There is no cheap DLC that gives players an edge like golden armor swords or unfair things like that. 

The games multiplayer is great and there is little lag for me and you can play arcade, the story, VS with other players and its not like the game needed that because the game is fun just playing by yourself. 

So do I recommend this game YES it has great challenge, it has some of the best replay value I have seen in a story, the gameplay is great  the collectibles are fun and worth getting, the multiplayer have 3 fun modes VS, story and arcade ( you can also play mini games in the story with others) and they are still making the game? It is worth it for sure and when they keep this system add more content, collectibles and things like that this game would be my new favorite game of all time. I really thing you should consider buying this game for a fun game to play buy your self and a fun game to play with friends. the only posible thing that the game could add to make it better would be local multiplayer. the game has good gameplay like castle crashers, replay value and collectables somewhat like MMO games and a short but sweet story.

22725758.review:
I will preface this by saying I JUST started playing the game to determine my first impressions about the gameplay.  I did this on purpose so that I wouldn't be distracted by all the fluff in this game.  There is, as you can already see, a very pleasant and deliberate art style.  It's inspired, of course, by the tested and established Zelda franchise.  The gameplay also feels a lot like Zelda.  There are other inspirations from SNES-era RPGs, of course, but this is the most salient to talk about - and I'll explain why.
When I say that this game feels like Zelda, I mean that in that it's both limiting and pleasant.  The walking speed is just about the perfect speed to be neither too fast or too slow - it's just pleasant.  The attack length is neither too much or too little - it's just pleasant.  At the same time, Grindea suffers from the same sort of creative stagnation that Zelda's combat had.  There's about 8 types of swords, 8 types of 2-handed swords, 1 bow to my knowledge (really, devs?).  To be fair, this is about the same level of variance that Link To The Past had in it's weapon variety.  But, if you're expecting a modern pc merging of Zelda swordplay and Diablo lootgrabbing, you will not find it here.  There's plenty of the former, none of the latter.  Even Secret of Mana - which you're undoubtedly going to compare this game to - had a more robust combat system where you had to time weapon swings and charge attacks... AND YOU HAD DIFFERENT WEAPONS BESIDES SWORDS!!
I want to be clear, though:  I am enjoying this game.  I'm going to be playing it.  It's too early to tell how good the skill tree is - but I can already tell that levelling up is EXTREMELY satisfying and rewarding.  There is huge potential in this game.  I just really hope that the devs can stop being held behind by LoZ:LTTP and just let their imaginations go - or that the fluff and story make this game worth it.

Secrets of Grindea is an RPG with real time combat like Zelda,and is fun to play with or without a friend,which is really rare on RPG with MP games.

Pros:
*No class restrictions (you can be a fire mage with a cloud and a ice friend protecting you,i'm serious)

*Puzzles,LOADS of puzzles,and you will need some time to think about some.

*Character creation,not much to talk about here,move along.

*Regions. They can vary from a city to a spoopy forest,and they are all fun!

*Combat,mixing skills,making awesome combos,and crafting another weapon to be stronger,REPEAT!

*Pixel art is great!

*The Story. The characters are lovable,and with time you will change your opinion about some,also,there's some plot twists here,funny jokes there,and TONS of sarcasm.

*Cards,or Monster Cards if you like,are rare drops from enemies,if you got a card from a enemy,it will give you a random bonus and a cute artwork from the enemy you killed,which is ALWAYS a plus in my book.

*Soundtrack is good

*Balanced (at least on normal mode),like the Yetis are MADE to tank your attacks,and some other enemies are made to be annoying.

*Easy to connect to MP through Steam and AWSOME controller support.

*THE EASTER EGGS!!!!!! I managed to find a Triforce near the pile of gold in the flashback sequence!!!! :D

*You can replay bosses to get more loot from them,well,everyone but...

Cons:

*You can't replay Winter's or the Mt. Bloom boss fights,I mean,the Winter boss was one of the most fun boss battles I ever saw,even if it didn't drop ANY loot,I would be playing it for ages,not for the Mt. Bloom boss fights,but they could have some extra loot and the replay feature anyway :|

*GRINDING,and i'm not a fan of it.It's not just walking in circles to begin a battle,you have to kill ALL enemies in the room to spawn another wave of enemies,although this sistem is great,it's boring to get the action going.

*The crafting system could be improved,like seeing the item kinda faded away,because my friend thought the ''red emmiter matrix'' was a calendar,that's right A CALENDAR. And there's not enough recipies...

*Not even at level 10 (max level of skills) my Frosty Friend could kill a Rabby in 1 hit,and a Rabby is the second enemy in the game,and it has ≅ 120 HP.

*The cards are just TOO rare to make it fun to grind,and it's based around luck too,so just to get a Jumpkin card,I had to stop my playthrough over how boring it was to get a 0,5% of card drop,to try again the other day :|

*The ''character portraits'' (the picture that appears when you talk to a character) are bad,they aren't pixelated,witch isn't that bad for itself,but they look more like a photo that has been glued there,the quality is horrible too.

Final Veredict:

9/10

It's a really fun game to play alone or with friends,if you like an ARPG I would recommend buying it.It also has a Talking Bag...

22560192.review:
I don't know what there is to say about this game that hasn't already been said. Despite its early access status, there is so much polish and attention to detail that, at a glance, it could pass as the finished product. I can tell the devs have put their hearts and souls into this game, and I'll be damned if it isn't paying off.

If I had to give praise to anything, it would be the skills and perks available. Players aren't locked into classes, so they have complete control over how their character develops and the niche they fill in battle. For instance, one-handed melee skills that deal multiple hits in one use benefit greatly from perks that improve critital hits. Then, tack on a movement speed bonus for charging skills or blocking with your shield, and you've built an acrobat that hits fast and hits hard.

Of course, there are so many other praises I could sing -- the cheeky jabs at RPG tropes, the deliciously roguelike arcade mode, the atmospheric and memorable soundtrack, -- but words can only do it so much justice. If you're on the fence about this game, do yourself a favor and try the demo. Pixel Ferrets, have yourselves a cup of coffee, on me.
